title: What Is Erythrocytosis?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributor

content: Erythrocytosis is when you have more red blood cells than normal. Red blood cells are also called erythrocytes.

Red blood cells carry oxygen throughout your body and remove carbon dioxide from your body. Your bone marrow (the tissue inside your bones) makes red blood cells and releases them into your bloodstream. Red blood cells live for about 120 days and then die.
There are two types of erythrocytosis, primary and secondary. While both cause an increase in red blood cells, each type happens for a different reason.

content_blocks.text: Erythrocytosis is when you have more red blood cells than normal. Red blood cells are also called erythrocytes.

Red blood cells carry oxygen throughout your body and remove carbon dioxide from your body. Your bone marrow (the tissue inside your bones) makes red blood cells and releases them into your bloodstream. Red blood cells live for about 120 days and then die.
There are two types of erythrocytosis, primary and secondary. While both cause an increase in red blood cells, each type happens for a different reason.

sections.heading: Types of Erythrocytosis
content: There are two types of erythrocytosis, primary and secondary. While both cause an increase in red blood cells, each type happens for a different reason.

Primary erythrocytosis. This type results from a problem in your bone marrow that causes it to produce too many red blood cells. Primary erythrocytosis can be either congenital, which means you were born with it, or acquired, which means you developed it later.

Secondary erythrocytosis. This type of erythrocytosis also happens when your body makes too many blood cells, but it is not caused by a problem with your bone marrow. This type usually happens because something affects your erythropoietin (EPO), which is a hormone that your kidneys make. EPO drives red blood cell production.

content_blocks.text: There are two types of erythrocytosis, primary and secondary. While both cause an increase in red blood cells, each type happens for a different reason.

Primary erythrocytosis. This type results from a problem in your bone marrow that causes it to produce too many red blood cells. Primary erythrocytosis can be either congenital, which means you were born with it, or acquired, which means you developed it later.

Secondary erythrocytosis. This type of erythrocytosis also happens when your body makes too many blood cells, but it is not caused by a problem with your bone marrow. This type usually happens because something affects your erythropoietin (EPO), which is a hormone that your kidneys make. EPO drives red blood cell production.

sections.heading: Erythrocytosis vs. Polycythemia
content: While erythrocytosis refers to a high red blood cell count, polycythemia is when you have more red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets than normal.

content_blocks.text: While erythrocytosis refers to a high red blood cell count, polycythemia is when you have more red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets than normal.

sections.heading: Causes of Erythrocytosis
content: Primary erythrocytosis can be a harmless disorder caused by a genetic trait that is passed down in families. If you only have too many red blood cells without having too many white blood cells or platelets, and you don't have secondary erythrocytosis, this may be why.

Primary erythrocytosis can also be caused by a type of blood cancer called polycythemia vera . Polycythemia vera is rare and develops slowly. You can have it for years before it's diagnosed. If it isn't treated, polycythemia vera can be life-threatening because the extra red blood cells can cause your blood to thicken and slow down. This can cause blood clots to develop.
Secondary erythrocytosis can have many causes. These can include:

Conditions that cause low oxygen. Your red blood cells carry oxygen to your body. If your oxygen is low for any reason, your body may increase its production of red blood cells to give you more oxygen. Conditions that can cause you to have a low oxygen level include:
bullets: Sleep apnea , which is a condition that causes you to stop breathing or breathe shallowly when you're sleeping
Hemoglobinopathy, which is a group of inherited blood disorders that affect the ability of your red blood cells to carry oxygen

sections.heading: Kidney disease
content: . The hormone EPO, which controls the production of red blood cells, is made in your kidneys. Problems with your kidneys, such as cysts, tumors, or narrowing of the arteries that go to the kidneys, can cause your body to make more EPO, which makes more red blood cells.
Some medicines. Anabolic steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs can cause your body to increase the number of red blood cells it makes.
Tumors . Some tumors secrete EPO. These can include tumors of the kidney, brain, liver, and uterus.

Dehydration . In some cases, you don't have too many red blood cells, but they are too concentrated because you don't have enough fluid in your bloodstream. This is called relative erythrocytosis and can be caused by burns , vomiting , diarrhea , or anything else that can cause dehydration, such as not drinking enough fluids.
Relative erythrocytosis can also be caused by diuretics , medicines that cause your kidneys to get rid of salt and water more quickly than normal.

This is called relative erythrocytosis and can be caused by burns , vomiting , diarrhea , or anything else that can cause dehydration, such as not drinking enough fluids.
Relative erythrocytosis can also be caused by diuretics , medicines that cause your kidneys to get rid of salt and water more quickly than normal.

sections.heading: Symptoms of Erythrocytosis
content: Many of the symptoms of erythrocytosis are caused by your blood flowing more slowly than normal. These symptoms can include:

content_blocks.text: Many of the symptoms of erythrocytosis are caused by your blood flowing more slowly than normal. These symptoms can include:

sections.heading: Diagnosing Erythrocytosis
content: Erythrocytosis is usually diagnosed first with a blood test. Your doctor will check the number of red blood cells you have as well as your EPO level. If your EPO level is low, your doctor may suspect primary erythrocytosis, such as polycythemia vera, and order a JAK2 gene test. A normal or high EPO level suggests a secondary cause, such as low oxygen, kidney problems, or EPO-producing tumors.

content_blocks.text: Erythrocytosis is usually diagnosed first with a blood test. Your doctor will check the number of red blood cells you have as well as your EPO level. If your EPO level is low, your doctor may suspect primary erythrocytosis, such as polycythemia vera, and order a JAK2 gene test. A normal or high EPO level suggests a secondary cause, such as low oxygen, kidney problems, or EPO-producing tumors.

sections.heading: Erythrocytosis Treatment
content: Treatment for erythrocytosis depends on the cause. Primary erythrocytosis may be treated with phlebotomy, which is when some of your blood is taken out to remove excess red blood cells and improve your blood flow. This is the primary treatment for polycythemia vera.
Secondary erythrocytosis is treated by treating the underlying cause. This treatment may include:
bullets: Oxygen for people who have low oxygen levels
Offering advice and support to help patients quit smoking
Treatment for any disorder causing low oxygen levels
Stopping any medicines that may be causing erythrocytosis

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Erythrocytosis is when you have more red blood cells than normal. Your genes, dehydration, and some medicines are a few of the triggers. Polycythemia vera, a type of blood cancer, can also be a cause. Primary erythrocytosis is treated with phlebotomy, which is when some of your blood is taken out to remove excess red blood cells and improve blood flow. Secondary erythrocytosis is addressed by treating the underlying condition.

Primary erythrocytosis is treated with phlebotomy, which is when some of your blood is taken out to remove excess red blood cells and improve blood flow. Secondary erythrocytosis is addressed by treating the underlying condition.

sections.heading: FAQs
content: Your body may have a high white blood cell count, also called leukocytosis, because it's fighting off infection or inflammation.

content_blocks.text: Your body may have a high white blood cell count, also called leukocytosis, because it's fighting off infection or inflammation.

meta_description: Erythrocytosis is when you have more red blood cells than normal. Learn more about what causes it, symptoms of erythrocytosis, and how it's treated.
